posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: Hey all, we’re attempting to use pathplanner’s override target rotation to aim at notes while we follow a pathplanner path, which works when we run it. Weirdly, we’re running into an issue where the second time and any subsequent times we run the command the drivetrain doesn’t move. We know its starting the command because the trajectory shows up on advantagescope but disappears after a second. Removing the override from the command group has the path working every time we run it, any ideas?

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
It would help a lot if you shared your code.

If I understand you correctly, you’re repeatedly running the robot in autonomous mode without deploying code and it works as expected the first time and doesn’t move after that.  Does it work if you redeploy the code or reboot the roboRIO?

What does the code for your rotation supplier do?  How are you creating it?  Are there any crashes in your log?  I note that the rotation static override is a static field in the class , so the second run will inherit the value from the first run until you set it.

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked:
Oh silly me I forgot to link it.

GitHub - SubZero-Robotics/2024-CommandRobot: 2024 robot code for FRC 5690 on our feature/object-detection-intake branch

We’re running our robot in teleop mode and telling it to follow a pathplanned path, this can be a preplanned path or a pathfinding command, either way after one run it wont run a second time. We know the command group is getting scheduled because our intake spins, the robot just doesnt drive to the pose, however after the path command times out the rest of the composition continues as normal.

For instance one of our tests is from our demo mode:

drive to note while aiming at note (pp on the fly)

drive to speaker (pp on the fly chained with pp preplanned)

shoot

The drive to the note doesnt work because it has a rotation override (but will work once) however after that command times out the drive to speaker still occurs

What’s really confusing is that this all works perfectly fine in simulation, and we can run it over and over without an issue. Removing the rotation override “fixes” the issue and the robot will follow the path, just without rotating to the correct pose

link_counts.title: GitHub - SubZero-Robotics/2024-CommandRobot: 2024 robot code for FRC 5690

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: Did you ever find a solution?  I did look over your code, but found nothing, so said nothing.

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: No solution, extremely confused about what could be the problem.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
What’s super-weird is that it doesn’t look as if the C++ library even honours the rotation target override.

C++ `PPHolonomicDriveController` ignores `rotationTargetOverride` opened 06:03PM - 25 Apr 24 UTC bovlb bug

C++ `PPHolonomicDriveController` ignores `rotationTargetOverride` opened 06:03PM - 25 Apr 24 UTC bovlb bug

opened 06:03PM - 25 Apr 24 UTC bovlb

opened 06:03PM - 25 Apr 24 UTC

bovlb

bug

From code inspection, the C++ implementation does not honour the rotation target … override.

https://github.com/mjansen4857/pathplanner/blob/05a123d86f47976c564564674fdb997e25b03773/pathplannerlib/src/main/native/cpp/pathplanner/lib/controllers/PPHolonomicDriveController.cpp#L59-L68

Compare with he Java implementation:

https://github.com/mjansen4857/pathplanner/blob/05a123d86f47976c564564674fdb997e25b03773/pathplannerlib/src/main/java/com/pathplanner/lib/controllers/PPHolonomicDriveController.java#L147-L156

I suggest that this should should instead say:
```c++
        units::radians_per_second_t rotationFeedback {
                        m_rotationController.Calculate(currentPose.Rotation().Radians(),
                                        targetRotation.Radians(),
                                        { maxAngVel,
                                                        referenceState.constraints.getMaxAngularAcceleration() }) };
        units::radians_per_second_t rotationFF =
```

https://github.com/mjansen4857/pathplanner/blob/05a123d86f47976c564564674fdb997e25b03773/pathplannerlib/src/main/native/cpp/pathplanner/lib/controllers/PPHolonomicDriveController.cpp#L59-L68

Compare with he Java implementation:

https://github.com/mjansen4857/pathplanner/blob/05a123d86f47976c564564674fdb997e25b03773/pathplannerlib/src/main/java/com/pathplanner/lib/controllers/PPHolonomicDriveController.java#L147-L156

I suggest that this should should instead say:
```c++
        units::radians_per_second_t rotationFeedback {
                        m_rotationController.Calculate(currentPose.Rotation().Radians(),
                                        targetRotation.Radians(),
                                        { maxAngVel,
                                                        referenceState.constraints.getMaxAngularAcceleration() }) };
        units::radians_per_second_t rotationFF =
```
